docs.lead_paragraph: A friend from Chicago showed up in Atlanta last week with Final Four tickets, a surprise gift from his sons. It was more of a bonding weekend than a fan fest; none of them had attended a college that was competing in the tournament. At breakfast, I asked them whom they were rooting for. Dad, a lawyer and a sophisticated news consumer, thought awhile before he picked Maryland. How could you not root for Juan Dixon, he said, a skinny orphan who worked himself into becoming an extraordinary player while staying four years in college? So it was the back story that did it. I argued for Indiana. Coach Mike Davis had actually returned to college in his 30's to get a degree, and he was overcoming a severe stutter and the ghost of his predecessor, Bob Knight.

headline.main: BackTalk; The Issue Is the Paltry Support for Supporting Players

docs.abstract: Robert Lipsyte BackTalk column, part of series on college sports, discusses contrasting motives of universities and athletes who make money for them; one school of thought suggests student-athletes should be paid to perform; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INVESTORS are searching for the real Janus. Throughout the bull market of the 1990's, the mutual fund group was closely identified with an aggressive growth style -- outsized bets on fast-growing companies with little regard to price. It delivered spectacular returns. After more than two dismal years, however, Janus has made big changes in its investments, in the process confusing many shareholders. The company's biggest holdings as of Jan. 31 included several stodgy companies like insurers and banks, and it even owned Philip Morris, the food and tobacco company. Janus Enterprise, among the most aggressive funds, kept about one-fifth of its assets in cash.

headline.main: Once Bold, Janus Shows Its Conservative Side

docs.lead_paragraph: Here are glimpses of some of the victims of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center. KIRAN GOPU Kept Up Family Ties No matter what cellular telephone plan he had, Kiran Gopu exceeded the limit of allowable calls. He talked to his friends constantly, and when his younger sister, Deepa, came to the United States from India, he called her every day. As a foreign graduate student studying at the University of Bridgeport for his master's degree in computer science, thousands of miles from his home in southern India, Mr. Gopu, 25, was intent on maintaining ties with his friends. When his former roommate Vamshidhar Velpula did not get into the graduate school of his choice, Mr. Gopu applied to Bridgeport for him.

docs.lead_paragraph: ATTENTION, New Yorkers and those who work in the city! Are you feeling sorry for yourself because the economy here is still crumbling? Are you envious of your fellow Americans who live where the recession seems to be over? Are you seriously considering trading your co-op on Columbus Avenue for a cottage in Columbus, Ohio, just because of the unemployment rate there is under 4 percent?

docs.lead_paragraph: DESPITE the slowing economy, three large Class A office projects are being built on Long Island without having primary tenants signed up. The new buildings will be in the heart of large commercial areas, such as Holbrook near Long Island MacArthur Airport, and Lake Success, midway between Long Island Jewish Medical Center and North Shore Medical Center.

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Thomas R. Suozzi, the county executive, laid out his four-year financial plan for Nassau County last week, he compared its notoriously shaky finances to another recent and infamous financial debacle. ''Just as with the Enron scandal,'' he said, ''a favored few were enriched and the rest of us were left holding the bag.'' He blamed the Republicans who ran the county before he took office in January for the projected deficit of $428 million.
docs.abstract: Article on Nassau County Executive Thomas Suozzi's belt-tightening plan aimed at closing projected $428 million budget deficit; plan includes $313 million in budget cuts, elimination of 1,200 county jobs and $115 million in new revenues from 19.4 percent property tax increase; union leaders warn that county services would suffer if work force is reduced and Republican lawmakers call tax increase crippling; photos; charts; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Starchy and dry, Edmund Stoiber, the conservative challenger to Chancellor Gerhard Schröder, becomes really animated about two things: economic data, which he reels off like a relentless professor, and the humiliating pit into which he believes Germany has fallen during the Schröder years. Asked why he wants to become chancellor in the Sept. 22 elections, Mr. Stoiber, 60, finally lets loose: ''We rank last in Europe in terms of economic growth. We have the biggest growth of unemployment in Western Europe. The stable Germany of the past gets a blue letter,'' a warning from the European Union about its increasing budget deficit. Moreover, he said, the president of Italy, Carlo Ciampi, ''said he was worried about the stability of the euro because of Germany.''

headline.main: For Dogged German Challenger, It's Still About the Economy

docs.abstract: Edmund Stoiber makes malaise of German economy his core issue in campaign to unseat Chancellor Gerhard Schroder in Sept 22 elections; Stoiber, candidate of Christian Democratic Union and his own Christian Social Union, gives interview with American journalists in advance of visit to Washington in which he tries to show his familiarity with foreign policy, urges even closer relationship with US and works to undercut any idea that he is provincial xenophobe, while defending restrictions on immigration; his perception as dour bureaucrat and 'Bavarian pit bull' puts him at disadvantage with the personable, telegenic Schroder; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: BEFORE Sept. 11, momentum had been building for Congress to pass some form of prescription drug coverage for Medicare recipients. But that and other domestic issues were put on hold after the attacks and the start of the Bush administration's anti-terrorism campaign. But now, more than six months later, prescription drug coverage is back on the front pages, thanks to the forces of rising drug prices and election-year politics.
docs.abstract: Fred Brock Seniority column on politicians' fear of rising anger among senior citizens about Medicare's failure to cover prescription drugs; notes people 65 and over make up 12.4 percent of population but account for 34 percent of all prescriptions filled and 42 percent of money spent on drugs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Elderly veterans struggling to cope with rapidly rising drug costs are pouring into the health care system of the federal Veterans Affairs Department, so severely straining its resources that in some parts of the country, thousands of them are waiting years to see a V.A. doctor. At Bay Pines V.A. Medical Center outside St. Petersburg, Fla., for example, 4,429 veterans, by the latest count, can look forward to their first doctor appointment in October 2005. And only a V.A. doctor can provide a prescription to be filled by a V.A. pharmacy.

headline.main: V.A. Health Care Strained By Big Wave of Enrollees

docs.abstract: Elderly veterans, struggling to cope with rapidly rising drug costs, are pouring into Veterans Affairs Department health care system, severely straining its resoures; veterans in some parts of nation are waiting years to see VA doctor, step needed to gain access to VA pharmacy; number of veterans enrolled in department's sprawling network of clinics, hospitals and pharmacies has doubled since mid-1990's, to six million; department's drug costs have risen 160 percent in same period, to $2.9 billion in 2001 from $1.1 billion in 1996, while its medical budget has risen just 42 percent; VA is trimming services to control costs; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Worst Drivers in New York Will Pay More'' (news article, March 30): Studies by the Insurance Research Council show that a large percentage of claims in New York's assigned-risk plan have a high suspicion of no-fault medical fraud. This fraud is tied to the fact that networks of lawyers work with medical care providers to overtreat minor injuries, using M.R.I.'s, physical therapy, massage, thermography, acupuncture, aromatherapy, biofeedback and the like.
docs.abstract: Letter by E John Cucci of Alliance of American Insurers links medical fraud to high auto insurance rates (S)
